items.title: Anima
items.description: Representing the feminine aspect of the psyche in Jungian psychology.

items.title: Bollingen
items.description: Inspired by Carl Jung's retreat at Bollingen Tower.

items.title: Burghölzli
items.description: Named after the psychiatric hospital where Jung worked.

items.title: Chiwantopel
items.description: Based on Jung's vision of an American Indian chief.

items.title: Dalada-Maligawa
items.description: Inspired by the Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic in Kandy, Sri Lanka.

items.title: Emma
items.description: Named after Emma Jung, Carl Jung's wife and fellow analyst.

items.title: Flüeli
items.description: Reference to Flüeli-Ranft, home of Swiss saint Nicholas of Flüe.

items.title: Fomalhaut
items.description: Named after one of the brightest stars in the night sky.

items.title: Konarak
items.description: Inspired by the Sun Temple at Konark, India.

items.title: Laufen
items.description: A dynamic exploration of movement and flow.

items.title: Maria
items.description: Description pending.

items.title: Pardes Rimmonim
items.description: Reference to the mystical Jewish text 'Garden of Pomegranates'.

items.title: Rejaf
items.description: Description pending.

items.title: Sanchi
items.description: Description pending.

items.title: Secret of the Golden Flower
items.description: Based on the Taoist text of spiritual awakening.

items.title: Sophia
items.description: Embodying divine wisdom and spiritual enlightenment.

items.title: Sousse
items.description: Description pending.

items.title: Sälig Lüt
items.description: Swiss German for 'Blessed People'.

items.title: Taos
items.description: Description pending.

items.title: The Diver
items.description: Symbolizing the journey into the depths of consciousness.

items.title: The Heart of the Mystic Rose
items.description: Description pending.

items.title: Tozeur
items.description: Inspired by the desert oasis in Tunisia.
